word.entryDescription: a small symbol or picture on a computer display that you select, usually by clicking on, to make something happen
word.entryExample: What do these icons represent?

word.entryDescription: very famous and well known
word.entryExample: Let's take a closer look at this iconic hat.

word.entryDescription: having a lot of ice
word.entryExample: I've driven a lorry on icy roads.

word.entryDescription: abbreviation for 'identification' – an official document that shows your name and date of birth, most often with a photograph
word.entryExample: You'll need your booking reference or some form of ID if you want to print your boarding pass at the airport.

word.entryDescription: the best something could be
word.entryExample: Our camps are in an ideal location.

word.entryDescription: in a way or situation that would be perfect
word.entryExample: Our three camps are ideally placed in beautiful locations along the south coast.

word.entryDescription: very similar or exactly the same
word.entryExample: Your daughter has bought two horrible pairs of identical sunglasses and two horrible identical hats.
The most identifiable feature about Albert Einstein is his hair.

word.entryDescription: information and details about who you are
word.entryExample: A lot of websites ask for your birthday, but it's an important way of checking your identity, and you shouldn't give it out unless there is a good reason to.

word.entryDescription: used to show that something might happen, and that something else depends on it
word.entryExample: Eat outside the museum if you bring food with you.

word.entryDescription: to start burning; to make something start to burn
word.entryExample: If the fuse had been connected to a rocket it would have ignited and taken off.

word.entryDescription: the moment when the fuel starts to burn
word.entryExample: When Steve shows us the flash, this is the ignition working.

word.entryDescription: sick; unwell
word.entryExample: Emma felt ill.

word.entryDescription: against the law; not legal
word.entryExample: Are these activities legal or illegal in your country?

word.entryDescription: in a way not allowed by the law
word.entryExample: A group of refugees entered the country illegally.

word.entryDescription: a condition caused by an infection or an internal problem which affects the normal function of the body or the mind
word.entryExample: Hepatitis is a serious illness.

word.entryDescription: a picture or drawing in a book, magazine etc, that helps make something clear or attractive
word.entryExample: This book contains 60 full-colour illustrations.

word.entryDescription: the way someone or something is seen or thought of by people
word.entryExample: Some details are only there to add to the image.

word.entryDescription: to form an idea or picture in your mind
word.entryExample: Can you imagine writing a novel?

word.entryDescription: the lack of balance
word.entryExample: When energy is in a state of imbalance, it is not equal.

word.entryDescription: without any delay
word.entryExample: The candidate will start work immediately.

word.entryDescription: the system in your body that fights against infection and disease
word.entryExample: A good variety of foods will ensure you get all the enzymes, vitamins, oils and minerals your body needs to be healthy and support a good immune system.

word.entryDescription: fair because of not being involved in something or not supporting either side of a disagreement
word.entryExample: We're looking for someone impartial who can mediate in this dispute.

word.entryDescription: annoyed by mistakes, having to wait, etc; not patient
word.entryExample: My husband is an impatient and plain-speaking man.

word.entryDescription: doing things suddenly without fully thinking about risks or effects; impulsive
word.entryExample: She is fiery and extrovert and lives an impetuous and carefree life.

word.entryDescription: brought from a foreign country
word.entryExample: Nowadays, loads of people eat imported food.

word.entryDescription: deeply affected; feeling admiration for somebody/something
word.entryExample: Critics and members of the public were very impressed with the variety, freshness and attention to detail in the album.

word.entryDescription: relating to Impressionism; painting in this style
word.entryExample: Impressionist painting has always been associated with spontaneity.

word.entryDescription: to get better
word.entryExample: The only way to improve in any sport is to practise.
What's in this box?

word.entryDescription: in a period of two weeks
word.entryExample: They would let me know in a fortnight.

word.entryDescription: in a very short time; very soon
word.entryExample: I'll send you the website with directions in a minute.

word.entryDescription: used to add more information to a statement
word.entryExample: In addition, we should turn out the lights when we leave a room, and not leave fridge doors open.

word.entryDescription: in a few words, with no details
word.entryExample: In brief, the date was a disaster.

word.entryDescription: used to end a piece of writing, speech, etc
word.entryExample: In conclusion, I believe that if everyone focused on making small changes, it would make a big difference to our natural world.

word.entryDescription: in a position that is before someone or something else
word.entryExample: The teacher stands in front of the whiteboard.

word.entryDescription: usually; in most cases
word.entryExample: In general, people are unhappier in the winter.

word.entryDescription: according to me
word.entryExample: In my opinion, this last argument is the most important.

word.entryDescription: in my opinion
word.entryExample: In my view, this is just wrong.

word.entryDescription: for the purpose of achieving something; used to talk about the reason or purpose of doing something
word.entryExample: She went to the post office in order to get the stamp.

word.entryDescription: ill, unwell
word.entryExample: The girl said that she was in pain.

word.entryDescription: in a few words; used to introduce a conclusion of a speech or a piece of writing
word.entryExample: In short, we have a plenty of choice where to go on holidays.
All people have things in common in spite of their own culture.

word.entryDescription: used to introduce a conclusion of a speech or a piece of writing
word.entryExample: In summary, this is the best film I've ever seen.

word.entryDescription: in the area of a picture behind the main subject
word.entryExample: This is a photo of Mary with Manhattan skyscrapers in the background.

word.entryDescription: at first; used to suggest a contrast with a later situation
word.entryExample: In the beginning TVs were really heavy.

word.entryDescription: after a long time and many actions or events
word.entryExample: In the end, Adam scored a goal in the cup final.

word.entryDescription: used to introduce the first of the series of points in an article, discussion, etc
word.entryExample: In the first place, I'm too tired, and in the second I don't really like horror films.

word.entryDescription: in the area of a picture that is closest to you when you are looking at it
word.entryExample: Who can you see in the foreground?

word.entryDescription: in the central area
word.entryExample: At the bottom of the picture in the middle there's a man with yellow spiky hair with jeans but no shoes.
